The False Claims Amendments Act of 1993 may be cited as the short title. The government has the right to dismiss certain actions. The False Claims Amendments Act of 1993 allows the government to move to dismiss a whistleblower's case within 60 days if the necessary facts were learned from a fraud investigation or public sources before the complaint was filed. If the person learned of the information underlying the alleged violation during their employment with the United States, they must disclose all evidence to the inspector general or supervisor before bringing an action. Additionally, the whistleblower must notify the Attorney General and their supervisor in writing of the disclosure, and if no action is taken within 12 months, the case may be dismissed. The Attorney General may seek an extension of the 12-month period for deciding on filing an action based on disclosed information. The supervisor of a person is defined as the next highest-ranking officer with supervisory authority over them. The motion to dismiss in a civil action must include documentation of allegations and evidence. The person bringing the action has the right to contest the motion, and access to evidentiary materials may be restricted by the court. If granted, the matter remains under seal. The Department of Justice must report on filed motions every 6 months. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO ACTIONS BARRED AND QUI TAM AWARDS. Section 3730 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to prohibit the waiver or release of a right of action for a violation of section 3729, except as part of a court-approved settlement. Additionally, all proceeds or settlement amounts related to allegations developed from information provided to the Government must be included in the proceeds of the action or settlement of the claim. In section 3730 of title 31, United States Code, changes are made to prevent the waiver or release of a right of action for a violation of section 3729, except in court-approved settlements. Proceeds or settlement amounts from information provided to the Government must be included in the action's proceeds or claim settlement. Amendments include striking out certain sentences in subsections. SEC. 4. WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION. Section 3730(h) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include whistleblower protection. An employee can seek relief if they can prove that a lawful act was a contributing factor in the employer's action against them. However, the employer can avoid liability if they can show with clear and convincing evidence that they would have taken the same action regardless of the employee's lawful act. SEC. 5. DEFINITION OF PERSON: Defines 'person' as any natural person, partnership, corporation, association, or legal entity, including states or political subdivisions.

SEC. 6. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS: Limits civil actions under section 3730 to be brought within 6 years of the violation of section 3729, with exclusions for periods when material facts were unknown to the US official with authority to act. SEC. 7. AUTHORITY TO ISSUE INVESTIGATIVE DEMANDS. Section 3733 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include "or an Assistant Attorney General" after "Attorney General" in various subsections. This amendment removes the designation requirement by the Attorney General in certain subparagraphs. Section 3733 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include "or an Assistant Attorney General" after "Attorney General" in specific subsections, removing the designation requirement by the Attorney General in those subparagraphs. SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY AND EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the date of enactment and apply to cases filed on or after that date. Provisions regarding specific sections of the United States Code will also apply to cases pending on the date of enactment. The Government may file a motion to dismiss a qui tam relator in certain cases within 120 days of enactment. The False Claims Amendments Act of 1986 and the Major Fraud Act of 1988 amendments apply to cases filed on or after their enactment dates, as well as cases pending on those dates that are still pending on the date of enactment of the current Act.
